div.p: Demand side management encourages the users in a smart grid to shift their electricity consumption in response to varying electricity prices. In this paper, we propose a distributed framework for the demand response based on cost minimization. Each user in the system will find an optimal start time and operating mode for the appliances in response to the varying electricity prices. We model the cost function for each user and the constraints for the appliances. We then propose an approximate greedy iterative algorithm that can be employed by each user to schedule appliances. In the proposed algorithm, each user requires only the knowledge of the price of the electricity, which depends on the aggregated load of other users, instead of the load profiles of individual users. In order for the users to coordinate with each other, we introduce a penalty term in the cost function, which penalizes large changes in the scheduling between successive iterations. Numerical simulations show that our optimization method will result in lower cost for the consumers, lower generation costs for the utility companies, lower peak load, and lower load fluctuations.

Further, the advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) [10] has made it possible to collect the usage data and to communicate with other AMI devices. With this data, the users can schedule the consumption of electricity using the energy-management controller (EMC) [6], [11]. A programmable logic controller (PLC) [12], [13] is then used which helps implement the proposed demand response algorithm and provides an interface between the appliances, sensors, and the controller. In addition, PLCs also provide modules to process signals that have special interfacing requirements [14]. Several companies developed commercial PLC based home energy management systems recently, see for example the products in [15] and [16].

The smart grid research community has been actively studying the various demand response problems. In [17], the authors study the energy scheduling problem under the assumption of known energy consumption for all the appliances; in [18], the authors study energy scheduling under the assumption of known operating times for all the appliances. Both works consider a single user scenario in order to find the optimal energy consumption. In [6], the authors find the optimal start times of the appliances in a system with multiple users, under the assumption of a known energy consumption for all the appliances. With this approach, there is a shift of peak load, but the peak load itself is not significantly reduced. In [19], the authors solve a similar problem in a distributed framework using a stochastic algorithm. They assume that each appliance has a flexible start time, but a fixed duration and energy consumption. In contrast, the authors in [11] propose an energy scheduling scheme where the start time and the end time are known a priori, and the energy consumption is varied continuously. They propose a distributed algorithm to find the optimal energy consumption schedule using tools from game theory. In this approach, the users are billed based on their total daily use of electricity, the distributed optimization is sequential, all users have to broadcast their schedules to all the other users in the system, and all the appliances are assumed to belong to the same class. In [20], the authors propose an energy consumption scheme by categorizing the appliances into two classes, and in [21], the authors propose a scheme with four classes. The appliances are characterized using a utility function and a set of constraints. However, the operating times of the appliances are assumed to be known a priori, and that the energy consumption can be varied continuously.

In this paper, we propose a distributed energy scheduling algorithm as a demand response for the smart grid. We use day-ahead pricing scheme, where the price of the electricity for the day is determined on the previous day. We then find optimal operating times for the electric appliances and their corresponding energy consumptions by minimizing the overall cost of operation. Our approach is different from the related work in four main aspects: i) we jointly optimize both the start time and the energy consumption for each appliance of the user; ii) we bill all the users based on their time-dependent use of electricity; iii) we enforce realistic constraints on the operation of the appliances by categorizing them into two different classes; iv) we let the energy consumption vary in a discrete manner, which is more realistic.

Further, our algorithm is fully distributed, where the only information available to the users is the prices for different time-periods. Using this price, each user will find his energy consumption schedule. Since we allow the energy consumption to vary in a discrete fashion, the corresponding optimization problem will be NP-hard. Therefore, we employ a greedy iterative algorithm to find the sub-optimal energy consumption schedule of each user. In each iteration, all the users will communicate their energy consumption schedule to the utility company. The utility company will then adjust the price depending on the overall system load and broadcast the price to all the users. The users will then update their energy consumption based on the new price. These iterations continue until convergence. We use numerical simulations to show that the proposed algorithm will result in lower cost for the consumers, higher profit for the utility companies, lower peak load, and lower load variance.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II we introduce the system model, where we describe the model for the users, model for the appliances, and the pricing strategy. We also formulate the problem of appliance scheduling as a centralized optimization problem. In Section III, we propose a distributed framework to solve the optimization problem, where each user employs a greedy approach. We provide numerical simulations in Section IV, and conclude the paper in Section V.

II. SYSTEM MODEL We consider a power system with one utility company (we refer to the utility company as "the utility" from now on) and users. For each user, an AMI measures the hourly consumption of electricity and communicates this consumption information to the utility. The AMI also communicates the price information from the utility to the users. A PLC is used to send the control signals for each appliance depending on the demand response algorithm and for each user, an EMC facilitates the communication between the appliances and the PLC and schedules the the appliances within a home. Fig. 1 illustrates the flow of the information and power between various blocks.

div.head: C. Model of Appliances
div.p: In this section, we describe the models of the schedulable electric appliances that are commonly used in the households. Our modeling of electric appliances was motivated by the smart appliance catalog in [26] and smart appliances survey report in [27]. Following these references, we broadly separate the electric appliances into two types, where each type is characterized by a set of constraints on the scheduling vector . 1) Type I: If any appliance belonging to the first type is switched ON at time , it has to remain ON until the task is finished. This constraint is usually called the "hold-time" constraint [28]. div.head: D. Optimization Problem
div.p: In this section, we formulate the problem of appliance scheduling as an optimization problem. In addition to considering the total bill that users pay for their energy consumption, we also consider the user preference in terms of their ideal start times and ideal operating modes in the optimization objective. Given complete knowledge about user preferences, we find the optimal scheduling by minimizing the global cost function: (13) In the above optimization problem, denotes the cost incurred by the appliance of the user for using it in the mode at time . The cost for each user comprises three parts, i.e., (14) The first part of the cost is the actual dollar amount the user pays to the utility for using the electricity. This cost for the appliance of the user is given as (15) Note that the cost matrix depends on the price vector , and hence on scheduling variables of all the users and all the appliances through (1), ( 4), ( 5) and (6).

The choice of the user in selecting the operating mode and operating time for each appliance will result in satisfaction costs which forms the second and the third part of the overall cost, respectively. The user satisfaction costs corresponding to changing the operating mode and the operating time should satisfy the following properties:

1) The user satisfaction due to the change in the operating mode and time of an appliances should enforce a high cost when the actual mode and time of operation are different from the user preferred operation mode and cost.

2) The satisfaction due to the change in the operating mode and time should be asymmetric around the ideal operating time and the mode, respectively. This asymmetry models the fact that the satisfaction the user obtains if his appliance is scheduled to operate one mode higher is not the same as the dissatisfaction incurred if the same appliance is scheduled to operate mode lower, and in the same manner models the fact that the satisfaction when an appliance is advanced by certain time is not the same as the dissatisfaction when the same appliance is delayed by the same time. In this paper, we quantify the satisfaction cost of the users due to operating mode mismatch using an exponential cost: (16) where is the ideal operating mode of the appliance of the user, and are constants specifying the how quickly the user gets dissatisfied as he moves away from the ideal mode. Note that the cost is asymmetric around the ideal operating mode. The reason for choosing the exponential cost is to satisfy the first property above that imposes high cost when the operating mode deviates from the ideal mode. Since the number of modes is in general small, using an exponential function imposes high cost.

The third part of the overall cost is the satisfaction cost due to delaying or advancing the operation of an appliance, and we quantify this satisfaction using (17) where is the ideal start time of the appliance of the user, and are constants specifying how quickly the user gets dissatisfied by advancing or delaying the operation of the appliance. Similar to , we consider exponential cost, and model it to be asymmetric around the ideal operating time. In general, the cost can be replaced by a weighted combination of the individual costs when the preference of the users for these various costs is different, i.e., (18) where and are the weights assigned to the cost functions for each user, such that . For example, for the users who are more sensitive to the money they pay to the utility, is greater than or . Solving the centralized optimization problem in (13) requires detailed information about user specifications and preferences, which is difficult to achieve in practice. Further the problem is non-convex since the cost term depends on scheduling matrices of all the users. In the next subsection, we propose a greedy distributed algorithm to find a sub-optimal solution to (13).

div.head: III. DISTRIBUTED OPTIMIZATION FOR LOAD SCHEDULING
div.p: In this section, we propose our distributed framework to solve the optimization problem described by (13). The idea of the distributed optimization is to allow users to individually minimize their own costs, which in turn reduces the global cost of the system and maximizes the social welfare. The strategy that the utility company uses is to set the prices of the electricity that will force the users to choose the load schedules which will minimize their individual cost as well as the overall global cost. In this manner, the price is used as an invisible hand to coordinate the interaction between the users and the utility.

Our approach for a distributed framework is inspired by the Walrasian equilibrium theory [29], [30]. A Walrasian equilibrium is defined as the tuple of the price and the user load profile matrices such that at price minimizes both the user cost and the utility cost defined in (7), under the load balance constraint given in (6).

The key result of the Walrasian equilibrium theory is the fundamental first welfare theorem [30] stated below: First Fundemental Welfare Theorem: If the tuple of the price and the user load profile matrices form a Walrasian equilibrium, then the load profile matrices are Pareto-optimal.

The implication of the welfare theorem is that when the users independently update their schedules such that are at an equilibrium, then none of the users will have any incentive to deviate from their respective schedules. Following Theorem 2 of [21], it can be seen that at the equilibrium, the price vector takes the form: (19) which is same as our pricing model in (5), which justifies our choice of the pricing model. Hence when the users independently minimizes their own cost by selecting the price to be proportional marginal generation cost 4 , the corresponding tuples will be in an equilibrium, and hence minimize the cost to the utility company.

This result motivates our distributed algorithm where the utility company and the customers jointly compute an equilibrium in an iterative manner. The user load profiles are all initialized according to their ideal start times and operating modes. Then, at the iteration: • The utility company sets the prices to be the marginal costs using ( 5) and ( 6), and broadcasts the price. • The user solves local optimization problems corresponding to all schedulable appliances , for , in response to the prices. The optimal scheduling matrix for the appliance of the user is obtained by solving: (20) Note that the cost is fixed and known to each user, since the price has been announced by the utility company.

• The user transmits his updated load profile to the utility. These iterations continue until convergence, and stop when the change of user load schedule in consecutive iterations is within a (small) preset threshold. The proposed algorithm is implemented at beginning of each day. The beginning of the day can be arbitrary. In this paper, we chose to be the beginning of the day. In this manner the price acts as an invisible hand to decouple the central optimization problem into several optimization problems. These optimization problems that correspond to different users can be solved in a parallel and a distributed manner.

In to coordinate the behavior among multiple users and to ensure that above algorithm converges, we modify the cost by imposing an additional penalty term. The use of such a penalty term was first proposed in [31] for tensor field estimation, and later used in [32] for demand response in smart grids with distributed generators. In both papers, the penalty term was the difference between successive iterates of the variable of interest. Motivated by these ideas, we introduce a penalty on a change of load schedule between two consecutive iterations for each user. However, since we are optimizing over binary matrices, the difference in the successive iterates of these matrices does not necessarily imply small changes in the load schedules between iterations. To alleviate this issue, we modify the cost at the iteration by adding an addition term:
where is a penalty coefficient, and

with and are defined as (23) Intuitively, the purpose of the penalty term is to penalize the large changes in the scheduling matrix between successive iterations. The selection of the penalty term determines the convergence of the algorithm. In this paper, we chose the penalty term to satisfy two requirements. First, we require significant changes in the user schedules in the beginning of the algorithm, but we want these changes to become smaller with iterations. Therefore we require penalty term be small in the beginning but increase with the iterations, and hence we chose the penalty coefficient to be proportional to the iteration index. Second, we want users with high cost to make large changes in their schedules, and users with small cost to make small changes. This is because users with high cost have a higher impact on the price and hence they should be allowed to schedule their usage without significant constraints. Thus, we choose the penalty coefficient to be inversely proportional to the cost of the users. We choose the penalty coefficient to be (24) Note that large strictly limits the step size, which slows down the convergence and small would not guarantee the convergence of the distributed optimization.

Each user solves constrained local optimization problems defined as (25) using the greedy algorithm described in the next subsection. After the users solve their respective optimization problems and find their scheduling matrices for all appliances, they compute the total load and report it to the utility. Thus, each user only reports his load profile to the utility instead of broadcasting it to all other users. Further, in order to find the scheduling matrices, each user needs only the price from the utility. In this manner each user only communicates with the utility and no other user in the network, which provides a greater user privacy.

div.head: A. Greedy Algorithm
div.p: Solving the individual user optimization ( 25) is NP-hard [33], and to obtain an approximate solution, we employ a greedy programming approach. Each user finds the scheduling matrix by selecting the best time and mode to operate his appliances. For each user, let denote a cost density, defined as (26) If is a type I device, the user chooses a pair that minimizes , sets , and marks the time as operating time. Then, for all the subsequent steps the user selects a time slot and a mode that minimize with an additional constraint that the chosen time should be adjacent to one of the operating times (already chosen). This process repeats until the total operating energy the the appliance is above the minimum operating energy. Note that if the cost densities are convex, then the above algorithm results in an optimal solution. For the scheduling problem in the paper, the cost densities are not convex, and hence the resulting solution is suboptimal. For a type II device, the user selects a time and a mode corresponding to the minimum value of , sets , and repeats this procedure in the subsequent steps until the minimum energy criterion is satisfied. Note that for the subsequent steps, there is no additional constraint that the selected time should be adjacent to the operating times. The cost corresponding to the solution obtained in this manner is then compared with the cost corresponding to a solution (if exists) in which the device operating at only one time (slot) satisfies the minimum energy constraint. Of these two solutions, we pick the one with the minimum cost. We remark here that for the type II appliances, the problem of energy scheduling is similar to the minimum knapsack problem [34], and our proposed greedy algorithm is sim- ilar to the greedy solution proposed to the minimum knapsack problem in [35]. div.head: A. General Setup
div.p: In this section, we describe the general setup for the numerical simulations. We considered a power system with one utility company, and 100 users . We divided a day into 24 time-periods, labeled as . There were ten appliance types , that included base load as well as schedulable load. Each device had a specific operating characteristics that are summarized in Table II. For example, the first appliance which is a type I non-schedulable appliance with one operating mode, that consumes 1.32kWh of energy each hour corresponds to a refrigerator. Similarly the characteristics of the third appliance correspond a washer-dryer that is schedulable. These appliance characteristics were taken from the smart appliance report in [27]. For each user, we selected a random number and types of appliances and the appliance characteristics were selected according to Table II.

For the generation cost of the utility company, we use the quadratic function, defined in (7), with parameters and . The profit coefficient was selected to be 1.20. For the costs , and , we chose and , respectively. All the appliances were initialized to start at their ideal start times and operate in their ideal modes before the beginning of the optimization algorithm. The iterations of the distributed algorithm were terminated when the change in the user cost between successive iterations falls below a threshold for all the users. We chose .

div.head: B. Simulation Results
div.p: In this section we show results using the setup described in the previous subsection. We also compare our results with a sequential optimization framework in which the users update their scheduling vectors sequentially. As a result of the sequential updates, there is no need to penalize the cost in this case and hence the penalty coefficient . Both the sequential and the distributed optimizations use the algorithm in Table I to find the optimal schedule of each device. In Fig. 2, we plot the generation of the utility company before using optimization, and after using the sequential and the distributed optimizations. The total daily generation did not change much after optimization, but the peak generation significantly dropped, as the users shifted a part of their on-peak load to off-peak hours. Overall, the hourly generation was leveled after the optimization. This leveling benefits the utility because by avoiding using expensive secondary generators to satisfy peak user load, and the reduced peak load is beneficial for the stability of the power grid. Further, the leveling was much significant after using the sequential optimization, but it comes at an additional implementation and communication overhead as each user has to communicate his schedule to a centralized processor to update the price.

In Fig. 3, we plot the generation cost of the utility obtained using the sequential and the distributed optimization methods as function of the iteration index. As it can be seen, the generation cost for the utility company decreases with the iteration index.

The overall user cost is plotted in Fig. 4 as a function of the iteration number. As it can be seen, the cost of all the users decreased with the iterations. The algorithm took about 30 iterations to converge.

The daily total daily bill (excluding the satisfaction costs for the mode and time deviations) for the user (in ) is calculated using the following equation: (27) where is the final price after the optimization. We plotted the daily user bill for the user set in Fig. 5. The results indicate that the daily total pay for the users decreased. In Fig. 6, we plot the total cost before and after optimization. As it can be seen, the total cost decreased after the optimization.

We also mention that for this 100-user system, the number of iterations for the distributed optimization depended on the selected . The distributed optimization was done in parallel, and thus the run time for each iteration is approximately of that of sequential optimization. The number of iterations for the distributed case decreased as increased. However, for a small , the algorithm no longer converges, as every user tries to schedule the appliance to minimize his own cost, thereby increasing the overall cost of the electricity due to an aggregated impact of their personal behavior.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we propose appliance scheduling as a demand response scheme for a smart grid. Unlike the earlier approaches that either select an optimal start time or an optimal energy consumption, our model finds a joint solution by considering all the appliances to be operating in specific modes. Such modeling is also realistic, since it is easier to design appliances that can switch between various modes depending on the energy consumption. We select the optimal price that the utility company has to charge to be proportional to the generation cost. We then propose a distributed framework, where each user independently minimizes his own cost using a greedy approximation. The overall optimal behavior is enforced using the price vector, which acts as an invisible hand coordinating the interaction among the users, and the convergence of the algorithm is enforced by introducing a penalty term that penalizes large changes in the user schedule between iterations. Numerical simulations validate the performance of the proposed algorithm.
